lead_paragraph: Brazilian officials said that Zika, a virus linked to brain damage in infants, may be causing an increase in the number of cases of Guillain-Barré, an autoimmune condition.

byline.contributor: Simon Romero reported from Rio de Janeiro and Donald G. McNeil Jr. from New York.
byline.original: By SIMON ROMERO and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr

snippet: Brazilian officials said that Zika, a virus linked to brain damage in infants, may be causing an increase in the number of cases of Guillain-Barré, an autoimmune condition.

headline.main: Zika Virus May be Linked to Surge in Rare Syndrome in Brazil
headline.print_headline: Virus in Brazil May Be Linked to a 2nd Illness

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

abstract: Brazilian doctors and officials say mosquito-borne virus called Zika, connected to severe brain damage in babies, may be causing hundreds of cases of rare Guillain-Barre syndrome, resulting in almost complete paralysis for weeks; CDC, which is still researching link between virus and autoimmune illness, warns that this could trigger another serious health crisis.
